Articles.Content:
So I’m working with a combined mining/refining vessel (Digger 7, I call it) to drill and process into fuel. It’s worked well on Minmus and the Joolian moons. 

 

But on Gilly, even once I’ve landed and stabilized (damned tiny gravity), I push my craft off the surface every time I deploy my two Drillomatics and have to land all over again. To make matters even trickier:

 

- After such a landing and bounce back, I can generally leave my drills deployed and they ease into the surface once I land again. BUT...

- If I deploy my drills prior to my initial landing attempt, the surface treats the drill tips as hard objects and the craft lands on them, toppling and/or bouncing back up. 

 

Anyone else observe this? Solutions? I’ve read references to “collision mesh” elsewhere but don’t really know anything about it.

My guess is that the drill is mounted to deep so the yellow static part of the drill hit ground then deployed 

As you see the drill engine is 1-2 meter below the bottom of the bottom of the mounting. 

One tricks might even be to use rcs to get lander an meter above ground then deploying drills.

If you get a serious kick away from the surface when deploying the drills, then they are probably indeed mounted too low on your craft.

If it is just a small kick, enough to get the landing legs of the ground, but not enough to get the drill heads out of the ground, then that's probably just Gilly being Gilly. I usually activate time-warp to steady my craft on Gilly.

P.S. I'll also let the moderators know to move this thread to "Gameplay Questions and Tutorials" where it fits better.

Moving to Gameplay Questions.

As folks have pointed out, the issue is that you've mounted the drills too low, so that the "solid" part of them is bonking into the surface. Mount rhem a bit higher up on your ship and you'll be fine.
